Under these circumstances it is advisable to 
mention some of the evidence which led to this general 
impression held by members of the Expedition. 
Throughout the winter when keen cutting winds 
blew past the ship it was often observed that on reaching 
certain limits in our walks we escaped both wind and drift. 
Such limits were a quarter to half a mile South of Cape 
Armitage and 'round in Seal Bay'. 
Many sledge parties started in a wind which 
was lost an hour or two later. As the sledge journeys 
to Cape Crozier became numerous it was recognised that 
parties going there direct would pass a belt of calms 
succeeded by Southerly and South Westerly winds and the 
course was curved to the Southward to avoid the soft snow 
in the calm region. 
Then came the extended sledge journeys when 
the prevalence of Southerly and South Westerly winds in 
the 'open' were so marked that arrangements for the use 
of Sledge sails were made in accordance with it. This 
prevalence is tabulated on page 490 as I have already 
mentioned.
